title-group.article-title: Views about neuromodulation interventions for depression by stakeholder group, treatment modality, and depression severity

article-meta.aff: aPennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 18602, USA
bMichigan State University, Grand Rapids, MI 49503, USA
cMichigan State University, 368 Farm Lane, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA
dMichigan State University, 509 East Circle Drive, Room 317, East Lansing, MI 48824, USA

author-notes.corresp: *Corresponding author at: Center for Neural Engineering, Department of Engineering Science and Mechanics, Research Associate, Rock Ethics Institute, Affiliate Associate Professor Huck Institutes of Life Sciences, The Pennsylvania State University, W-316 Millennium Science Complex, University Park, PA 16802, USA. lcabrera@psu.edu (L.Y. Cabrera).

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the CC BY-NC-ND license (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/).

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The past few decades have seen the emergence both of new neuromodulation treatment protocols and novel applications of standard neuromodulation interventions in psychiatry. Yet little is known about different stakeholders’ views about these interventions.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We administered an online survey with an embedded video vignette experiment to four national samples: the general public (N = 1022), caregivers for people with depression (N = 1026), patients living with depression (N = 1050), and board-certified psychiatrists (N = 505). We randomly assigned subjects to one of eight conditions in our full factorial design: four neuromodulation interventions [electroconvulsive therapy, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation, deep brain stimulation, or adaptive brain implants] by two depression severity levels [moderate or severe]. In this paper we present results from ANOVA and linear regression models explaining how views about these four neuromodulation interventions—as measured in five attitudinal scales (general affect, perceived influence on self, perceived benefit, perceived risk, and perceived invasiveness)—vary by (1) intervention, (2) depression severity, and/or (3) stakeholder group.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Our results provide evidence that psychiatrists views differ significantly in important ways from other stakeholder groups. Type of intervention also shaped participants’ attitudes, including perceptions of invasiveness, effectiveness, and safety.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: Given the differing affective valence among stakeholders and the differences found by modality and stakeholder groups across the different scales, future targeted educational initiatives could be developed to help address key misunderstandings and misinformed perceptions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Personal values and experiences shape attitudes and beliefs about mental health treatments. When people are uninformed or misinformed about the merits and use of a therapeutic intervention, these views can prevent them from accepting the intervention and reduce needed referrals for the treatments [1]. Conversely, uncritical and unrealistic expectations together with unbridled enthusiasm could lead to premature acceptance and adoption of novel therapies. Historically, psychiatric treatments have been met with uneven public reception. For example, before the first psychiatric medications were available, clinicians, caregivers, and the public rapidly endorsed unproven somatic psychiatric treatments for desperately ill patients, such as frontal lobotomies [2,3]. By contrast, with regard to electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), negative attitudes have persisted despite sound scientific evidence regarding its safety and efficacy [4–6].

To better understand both over- and under-estimation of the potential benefits of a treatment, it is important to understand (a) how stakeholders’ ethical concerns, beliefs, and attitudes about neuromodulation interventions may vary across stakeholder groups, type of intervention, and differences in disease severity. Our project focuses on four neuromodulation and neurostimulation interventions—ECT, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), deep brain stimulation (DBS), and adaptive brain implant (ABI)—which we will refer hereafter as psychiatric electroceutical interventions (PEIs). We use this terminology because electroceuticals (which employ electromagnetic interventions) offers a nice contrast to pharmaceuticals (which employ chemical interventions); it accurately describes the different technologies we are examining (both neuromodulation and brain stimulation); finally, “psychiatric” as a modifier of electroceuticals helps to further indicate that we are focused specifically on their use in treating depression. We selected those interventions because their development and characteristics vary in theoretically interesting ways. ECT and rTMS are FDA approved for treating MDD but have different levels of public acceptance. DBS and ABIs are emerging technologies that require neurosurgical implantation. We focus on major depressive disorder (MDD) since it represents the heaviest burden among mental and behavioral disorders in the US and because all 4 PEIs are used or proposed for use for this disorder.

Three shortcomings limit the generalizability of most existing studies of attitudes and ethical views about PEIs. First, they tend to use small, non-representative samples. Second, they tend to include only one stakeholder group. Third, these studies mostly examine views about using ECT [4,5,7,8] or about using DBS for treating Parkinson’s Disease [9–11]. To address these limitations and support the responsible and ethical development and use of PEIs, we conducted a study to examine the views about the above four interventions among a large national sample of four key stakeholder groups in the United States (US): medical professionals, patients, caregivers, and the general public.

sec.title: Survey research on PEI attitudes
sec.p: Most research examining attitudes toward PEIs focuses on ECT, likely because it has been in use for the longest time and is regarded as controversial by some. Most studies involving psychiatrists find they consistently report more favorable attitudes toward ECT than do other medical providers or patients [12–16]. Studies involving only non-clinicians have less consistent results [17]. Some find that patients and relatives report positive attitudes toward ECT [12,18–20], while others report negatives views [21,22]. Studies including members of the general public find that this group tends to view ECT most negatively of all stakeholder groups [4,7,8,23]. For example, Wilhelmy et al. report rather low levels of awareness, knowledge, and acceptance of ECT among respondents to their online survey administered to the German general public [8].

Far fewer studies analyze attitudes toward rTMS, with most examining the views of psychiatrists. Alhadi and colleagues [24] find that most of the psychiatrists they surveyed have a positive attitude toward rTMS, while Stern [25] reports that most psychiatrists in their sample are willing to refer patients to rTMS in the future. A more recent study finds that Chinese psychiatrists tend to have negative attitudes about using rTMS [26]. Two surveys of patients find them reporting generally positive views about using rTMS for depression [27,28]. We are not aware of any survey studies examining public views of the use of rTMS for mental health disorders.

While DBS is still being examined in clinical trials for most psychiatric interventions, a few studies do investigate clinicians’ and patients’ attitudes toward this intervention. Naesstr [29] finds that nearly all Swedish psychiatrists surveyed about using DBS as a therapy for OCD were positive about its use. In a survey of Canadian psychiatrists’ and residents’ views of psychiatric neurosurgery, Cormier finds that clinicians prefer to refer patients with OCD for DBS rather than for anterior cingulotomy or capsulotomy; however, most sampled clinicians consider their DBS knowledge to be weak or poor, and approximately one-third believe DBS to be dangerous [30]. Leykin and colleagues report that patients with MDD in the United States tend to hold positive attitudes toward DBS research [31]. Ali and colleagues report that most health care providers surveyed about using DBS to treat addiction agree that potential participants in clinical trials of DBS for addiction should be ‘severely’ addicted [32].

Relatively few studies report the influence of social or demographic characteristics on attitudes toward PEIs, but there is some evidence that age and education influence them. For example, Lauber and colleagues [4] find that older adults report less negative ECT attitudes than do their younger counterparts. Alexander and colleagues [33] find that more highly educated members of the public report more positive ECT attitudes than do their lesser educated counterparts.

Our survey project builds on prior research, including an early phase of the project where we conducted interviews [6,34], to examined four stakeholder groups’ views about four PEIs used to treat MDD. We empirically test the following hypotheses with our survey results.
Hypothesis 1. Ethical concerns, beliefs, and attitudes about PEIs vary across stakeholder groups.
Hypothesis 2a and 2b. Ethical concerns, beliefs, and attitudes about PEIs vary by (a) intervention type or by (b) depression severity.
Hypothesis 3a and 3b. The influence of stakeholder group membership on ethical concerns, beliefs, and attitudes about PEIs varies by (a) intervention type or (b) depression severity.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: We tested these hypotheses with data gathered from a standardized survey with an embedded video vignette experiment that was administered online via Qualtrics to four large US samples of the general public, caregivers, depressed patients, and board-certified psychiatrists between April and June 2020. We employed a between-subjects 4*2 full factorial design for our embedded experiment, which has been used with considerable success in several fields [35–38]. The two factors—intervention type (DBS vs. rTMS vs. ECT vs. ABIs) and disease severity (moderate vs. severe depression)—produced eight total conditions into which respondents were randomly assigned. All participants received the same set of core questions, in addition to a few different questions unique to each stakeholder group. We focus here on five novel scales, which we validated in a number of pilot studies, measuring key ethical concerns, beliefs, and attitudes about PEIs (i.e., PEI views) (See Section 2.4). We conducted this study in compliance with a human subjects exemption from the Michigan State University Institutional Review Board.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: To draw our three non-clinician samples, we contracted with Qualtrics, which manages a large internet panel (i.e., sampling frame) designed to capture the demographic diversity of the US adult population. For our general public stakeholder group, Qualtrics drew a quota sample of 1022 adults from this sampling frame that matched US population estimates of age, sex, race, and income from the US Current Population Survey. For our caregiver stakeholder group, Qualtrics applied a screening question in addition to the population estimate matching to select 1026 adults who were currently serving as the primary caregiver for someone with depression. For our patient stakeholder group, Qualtrics drew a quota sample of 1050 adults with depression from a separate internet panel of adults who had previously reported having a depression diagnosis. Our patient sample matched age, sex, and race estimates of the US adult population living with depression [39].

Our research team managed the recruitment and sampling of our psychiatrist stakeholder group. Our sampling frame contained the 49,431 board-certified psychiatrists listed in the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology directory in late 2019. We used stratified random sampling—stratifying by state—to contact 16,190 US psychiatrists across all 50 states. Employing the Tailored Design Method [40], widely considered as best practice in survey research, we contacted this group multiple times via postal mail and email—achieving a sample of 505 US psychiatrists who fully completed our survey. Table 1 below displays key social and demographic characteristics for each of our four samples in this study.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p: After providing informed consent, participants answered preliminary questions and viewed a randomly assigned video vignette [41,42] before answering questions assessing their understanding of the experimental message [43]. We carefully crafted and filmed the video vignette—featuring professional actors playing a patient with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) receiving information about a PEI from her psychiatrist highlighting the depression severity (moderate or severe) [44–46]. Our vignettes were independently reviewed by our Scientific Advisory Board members, another psychiatrist not on the study team, and four other adults (via cognitive testing) to ensure their quality, comprehensibility, and neutrality. After answering initial questions about the video vignette, participants answered several questions measuring key views about the intervention featured in their video as well as their demographic, social, and political characteristics.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Within each of these instruments, we randomized the item order to eliminate question order effects [40]. Our Supplemental Digital Content (SDC) provides the full text for all of the items in each of these scales.

We also measured participants’ perception of how bad it would be to live with TRD every day with a single-item (bad daily life with TRD) ranging from “moderately bad” (1) to “extremely bad” (10). In addition, we measured six demographic, social, and political characteristics that we employed as controls in our statistical analyses. We measured sex (“male” = 0; “female” = 1) and race (“non-white” = 0; “white” = 1) with dummy variables. Age varied from “18–24” (1) to “65 or over” (6), and educational attainment varied from “high school diploma or GED” (1) to “graduate degree” (4). We measured political ideology along a unidimensional scale from “very conservative” (1) to “very liberal” (7), and we measured religiosity as the frequency of religious service attendance, ranging from “never” (1) to “at least once every week” (6).

sec.title: Analytical techniques
sec.p: We conducted our analyses in three stages with IBM SPSS 26.0. First, we performed a series of one-way ANOVAs to examine the differences in means on our five PEI views scales across stakeholder groups and assigned PEI modality. Second, to formally test Hypotheses 1, 2a, and 2b, we ran a series of multiple ordinary least squares (OLS) regression models to examine variation in these five PEI views by stakeholder group, PEI modality, and depression severity, while accounting for respondents’ demographic, social, and political characteristics. We modelled the main effects of the experimental factors (i.e., PEI modality and depression severity) and stakeholder group membership (i.e., psychiatrists, patients, caregivers, and members of the public) with dummy variables, with ECT modality, moderate depression, and psychiatrist group as the reference groups, respectively. Third, to formally test Hypotheses 3a and 3b, we included in these multiple OLS regression model interaction terms to examine whether the influence of stakeholder group membership on PEI views is statistically moderated by PEI modality or depression severity.

To reduce the likelihood of multicollinearity problems associated with using higher-order (e.g., interaction) terms in regression models, we created our interaction terms using centered scores (mean – value) [47].

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The ANOVA results in Table 2 provide preliminary evidence that participants’ ethical concerns, beliefs, and attitudes vary across stakeholder group and by intervention. The F-statistic for each ANOVA was statistically significant. Stakeholder group and PEI modality have more influence on general affect, perceived risks, and perceived invasiveness than they have on perceived influence to self and perceived benefits.

In subsequent sub-sections, we present the results that bear upon Hypothesis 1 (H1) in Table 3, H2a and H2b in Table 3, and H3a and H3b in Table 4, respectively. For further visualization of how PEI views differ by stakeholder group and intervention type please see Fig. 1 and Fig. 2.

sec.title: Psychiatrists’ views differ from those of non-clinician groups
sec.p: Table 3 reports the standardized coefficients from multiple OLS regression models explaining the five PEI views by stakeholder group membership (with psychiatrists as the reference category), PEI modality (with ECT as the reference category), and depression severity—while controlling for the participants’ demographic, social, and political characteristics as well as their perception of how bad it would be to live with TRD every day. Non-clinicians reported less positive affect toward their assigned PEI than did psychiatrists, even though the former perceived greater benefit of their assigned PEI than did the latter. Psychiatrists having an overall positive affect toward their assigned PEI reflects a similar pattern found in other studies looking at factors associated with a positive attitude toward ECT by psychiatrists [15]. While there are studies showing that patients and their relatives with ECT experience hold a positive attitude toward ECT [18], our results do not support those findings. This could be due to the fact that our patient sample was not limited to those who have undergone a given intervention. Regarding members of the public, our results aligned with previous findings regarding less positive attitudes [7]. These patterns of affect across stakeholder groups are likely to be driven by psychiatrists having more knowledge, awareness and experience with these interventions than the other stakeholder groups, and as such fewer misconceptions related to unfounded portrayals of these technologies, whether negative or positive. In terms of perceived benefits, the study by Lutchman et al. [48] also found that psychiatrists were most likely to regard ECT as more beneficial than harmful, and Taieb et al. found that patients who have undergone ECT considered it a helpful treatment [49]. Yet our results show no significant difference in benefit perception across stakeholder groups regarding ECT. Moreover, compared to psychiatrists, members of the caregiver and patient groups were most likely to perceive more benefits to rTMS and DBS.

Compared to psychiatrists, non-clinicians also perceived greater risk and greater invasiveness from their assigned intervention than did their psychiatrist counterparts. It is likely that psychiatrists’ experiences with different medical procedures and their perceptions of their benefit-risk balance [50] shape their perceptions on invasiveness. A study by Lutchman and colleagues [48] found that the majority of psychiatrists surveyed regarded ECT as less dangerous than major surgery. Similarly, psychiatrists in our study perceived their assigned PEI as less risky than did any of the other stakeholder groups, and they viewed ECT as less risky than adaptive brain implants. One reason for this, as Leykin and colleagues’ [31] findings suggest regarding DBS, is that for the implantable PEIs the brain surgery involved poses risks inherent to those interventions. Non-clinicians groups’ risk perceptions, in particular those related to ECT, are similar to those reported in previous literature on patient and public attitudes connected to the possibility of memory problems and of brain damage [4,6–8,23] despite the fact that any effects on memory are usually short-lived and that brain damage only occurs in the setting of prolonged anoxia, a risk made irrelevant by modern anesthetic techniques. The reasons for this general aversion can be connected to perceived similarities between ECT and historical invasive treatments, such as frontal lobotomy, in psychiatry, and to fears of directly intervening on the brain, using electricity on humans, and linking the use of electricity with punishment and social control (e.g., people might associate the use of electricity on the body with the electric chair, and previous uses of psychiatric interventions).

Members of the general public perceived their assigned PEI to have less positive influence on self than did psychiatrists, though other non-clinicians’ perceived influence on self did not differ statistically from that of their psychiatrist counterparts. One way to interpret our results, which is supported by our interview findings and other studies [29], is that psychiatrists think of positive changes of important elements of personality and self as an intended outcome of the intervention, rather than a side-effect or unwanted result. This interpretation contrasts with the vast neuroethical discussion on the ethical issues raised by the possibility of stimulation-induced changes in personality or self, which focuses mainly on unintended effects of PEIs on the self.
Overall, these results provide compelling evidence in support of H1 that PEI views vary across stakeholder groups.

sec.title: PEI views by PEI modality and depression severity
sec.p: Views and perceptions around PEIs also varied based on the type of intervention examined. Compared to participants assigned to the ECT condition, those assigned to the rTMS condition reported more positive affect, more positive influence on self, greater perceived benefit, lesser perceived risk, and lesser perceived invasiveness. This is consistent with descriptions in the literature of rTMS as non-invasive and safe, and is also consistent with the few attitudes studies focused on rTMS [25,27,28,51]. Compared to ECT, rTMS was also perceived as having more positive influence on self than the other modalities; however, looking at the interaction effects between modality and stakeholder group the picture is less clear (See Section 3.3). In particular, most literature covering ECT and even clinicians’ attitudes about ECT tend to view ECT as a technology with great potential to alleviate symptoms, whereas for rTMS, there are still doubts about its place in treatment. More research is needed to better understand these differences.

The patterns with the two implantable PEIs were weaker and less consistent. Briefly, participants assigned to the DBS and ABI conditions reported less positive affect and greater perceived invasiveness than did their ECT condition counterparts. Further, participants in the ABI condition reported greater perceived risk than did those in the ECT condition. These views reflect to a certain extent the nature of these applications, as implantable PEIs required brain surgery, yet they are in contrast with optimistic media portrayals of the use of DBS for psychiatric disorders [52].

Depression severity only moderately influenced participants’ views on affect and perceived influence on self. Compared to participants assigned to the moderate depression condition, those assigned to the severe depression condition reported more positive affect and more positive influence on self. It is possible that the more severe participants perceived depression to be (which correlated with our experimental condition (0.184**)), the more they thought these interventions could help in alleviating the symptoms. We also asked participants about how bad they thought it was to live with TRD, and we found similar findings to a previous study related to harmfulness of medication perceptions [53], in that the worse our participants saw life with TRD, the more likely they were to perceive benefits of the interventions and perceived them as less risky. These results provide solid evidence in support of H2a and H2b that PEI views vary by PEI modality and depression severity, respectively.

sec.title: Influence of stakeholder group membership on PEI views by PEI modality and depression severity
sec.p: Table 4 reports the standardized coefficients from multiple OLS regression models that are identical to those displayed in Table 3 except they also contain a suite of interaction terms to investigate whether the influence of PEI modality or depression severity on PEI views varies across stakeholder groups. Many of these interaction terms have statistically significant effects, though not consistent ones across all of the models. Nevertheless, we draw attention to the most discernable patterns here.

First, assignment to the rTMS condition slightly moderates the influence of public and patient group membership on one and two PEI views, respectively. Specifically, members of the general public in the rTMS condition reported slightly more positive influence on self than did their respective counterparts in the ECT condition, whereas depressed patients in the rTMS condition reported both slightly more positive influence on self and benefits than did their respective counterparts in the ECT condition. Second, assignment to either implantable PEI condition substantially moderates the influence of non-clinician group membership on several PEI views. That is, members of the general public, caregivers, and patients in either the DBS condition or the ABI condition reported considerably more positive views and slightly less negative views of their assigned PEI than did their respective counterparts in the ECT condition. Third, there is no evidence that depression severity moderates the influence of stakeholder group membership on PEI views. Overall, these results provide considerable evidence in support of H3a that the influence of stakeholder group membership on PEI views varies by PEI modality, but they provide no evidence to support H3b that the influence of stakeholder group on PEI views varies by depression severity.

sec.title: PEI views by socio-demographic characteristics
sec.p: Returning to the direct effects in Table 3, we briefly describe the performance of the remaining variables in these models. For the most part, these variables accounted for little of the adjusted R2 values across the models. The worse that participants perceived living with TRD, the more positively and less negatively they viewed their assigned intervention. Religiosity was the sociodemographic variable with the most influence across all five scales; those with higher levels of religiosity generally had more positive views of PEIs. Few studies have linked attitudes around mental health interventions and religiosity; the few that report on this do not have a consistent pattern. For example, Harris and colleagues [54] found a positive relationship between religious service participation and use of mental health care. Other studies have found that religiosity is associated with more negative attitudes toward science [55] while others do not show a consistent pattern in predicting risk perception [56]. While there is a large literature on the role that religion has in potentially offering explanations for mental health problems and as a source of comfort [57,58], further study is needed related to PEIs.

Educational attainment also had an important role in positively shaping affect, perceived influence on self, and perceived benefit of the assigned PEI. This is similar to previous findings on ECT and attitudes. Alexander and colleagues [33] found that participants with higher levels of education had more positive attitudes toward ECT than those with lower levels of education. Yet, public attitudes studies have found mixed results on the role of education and support for psychotropics. For example, a Swedish survey found more favorable attitudes to medication in people with higher educational attainment [59]. Coppens et al. [60] also found that lower educational level was associated with lower perceived value of professional help, which can be related to views on psychiatric treatments. These findings seem to reflect the role that knowledge and experience have in shaping attitudes and perceptions as mentioned above. However, Angermeyer et al. [61] found that in Germany and Nobosibirsk, there was an inverse relationship between educational level and acceptance of psychotropic medication for treatment. Jorm et al. [62] in their Australian sample found that having a university degree was less common in those who thought antidepressants would be harmful compared to those who said they would be helpful.

Compared to their male counterparts, females reported less positive affect, less perceived risk, and less perceived invasiveness of their assigned PEI. The role of gender has shown inconsistent findings in prior studies examining depression therapies. For example, Jorm et al. [62] and Isacson and Bingefors [59] found no relationship between gender or age group and antidepressant beliefs or harmfulness beliefs of antidepressants, respectively. Although in a more recent survey, Reavley and Jorm [53] found beliefs about the harmfulness of antidepressants to be more common among men, which is similar to our results with PEIs and risk perceptions. A study by Sigurdsson et al. [63], found that women do not differ from men on their perceptions of ECT as being effective, which reflects our findings of no gender differences in perceptions of PEI benefits. Our finding related to women being less likely to see their PEI as risky and invasive, is in contrast with previous findings on emerging technologies, though this pattern changes depending on the modality at stake, with women perceiving ECT and TMS as more invasive than the implantable PEIs, and ECT as riskier.

sec.title: Strengths and limitations
sec.p: One of the main strengths of this survey is the large national sample of stakeholders in the USA, representing different key players in the use of four different neuromodulation interventions. There are other interventions that, for practical reasons, we could not cover, including transcranial direct current stimulation and vagal nerve stimulation. Future work should examine how our results relate to those of these other interventions. We also ensured the robustness of our data by implementing attention checks that were used to filter responses for the final analytic set. Our video vignette enabled a more dynamic way to expose participants to the experimental condition. Although efforts were made to ensure that survey questions were interpreted the same way across stakeholder groups, for the psychiatrists or patients with severe depression groups the vignette might not have seemed as realistic as for the other stakeholder groups.

Finally, we recognize that the four interventions we compared not only vary in their level of physical invasiveness, but also in their selectivity and focality, their current approval status for clinical use, and the level of TRD a patient must exhibit to be a candidate for them. These factors may have influenced participants’ responses, even though random assignment should have neutralized this influence across experimental conditions. We developed the video vignette’s hypothetical scenario to provide an equivalent point of comparison, even further mitigating this influence. This helped us achieve our aim of anticipating potential barriers and ethical concerns with these interventions beyond those associated only with their current use. Future work will focus on analysis related to the role of experience and familiarity with PEIs or other psychiatric treatments, as well as the source of information.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Given the therapeutic potential of neuromodulation interventions, it is necessary to examine the perceptions of different stakeholders, including psychiatrists, patients with depression, caregivers, and members of the general public, to better understand their attitudes and perceptions related to risk, benefits, influence on self, and invasiveness of these interventions. Our results provide new information about factors influencing stakeholders’ attitudes toward a given intervention for depression. The results of our survey can serve as the foundation for future stakeholders to help ensure that the process of informed consent addresses all issues that patients perceive as important to their decision-making, and what topics may be perceived as relevant by different stakeholder groups with specific sociodemographic backgrounds. Future work also should aim to employ more sophisticated techniques (e.g., structural equation modeling) to model both direct and indirect effects in path analyses. Our findings also highlight the need for future surveys to replicate this study while also considering other stakeholders, other countries, other neuromodulation interventions (such as vagus nerve stimulation and transcranial direct current stimulation), and other psychiatric indications (e.g., the use of rTMS or DBS in treating addiction).

ack.p: This study was supported by a BRAIN Initiative grant (#RF1MH117802) from the US National Institute of Mental Health to (PI: LC). The funding source had no influence on the study design; the collection, analysis, and interpretation of data; the writing of this manuscript; or the decision to submit the manuscript for publication. We thank Gerald R. Nowak for his help with data management.

caption.p: Comparison of affect across PEI modality by stakeholder group.
Comparison of Perceived A) Invasiveness, B) Influence on Self, C) Risk, and D) Benefit across PEI modality by stakeholder group.
